title: If you want to promote "game clarity", shouldn't the AS gains listed on items and abilities change?
body:
And have them calculated on the spot and show exactly how much AS someone will gain on the item description?

You are using an AS calculation system that has the Base AS as a core for all AS gains, yet the way AS gains are listed don't give that impression.

You see players saying "Tristana's Q doubles her attack speed", which is a completely oblivious statement and they don't understand that her Q always gives the same amount of AS for each rank. The way you describe them, you make the players who haven't searched on it think that abilities will also scale with AS items, something that is obviously not the case.

So, items and abilities should show exactly how much AS a champion will gain, it's only logical when you call yourself advocates of "in-game clarity". Additionally, having the AS gains listed as percentages imposes a "burden of knowledge" on how the AS calculations work behind the final numbers and that's also something else you have claimed to be against.

replies.body:
Rabadon's does list the bonus AP on the tooltip.

I'm actually surprised that Attack Speed scaling is confusing for some players. It works the exact same was as Critical Strike Chance does: You just keep adding the percentages together.

But that's interesting. I think we should definitely do something to at least improve the problem.

I have a team of Fiddles, Darius, and Trist. They're all level 9. They have no runes and no masteries. They all buy PD.

Crit chance for Fid: 0 + 30% = 30%.
Attack Speed for Fid: [(0.625)/(1+0)] x [100 + (2.11 x 9) + 50]% = 1.05 Attacks per second

Crit chance for Darius: 0 + 30% = 30%
Attack Speed for Darius: [(0.625)/(1-0.08) x [100 + (2.65 x 9) + 50]% = 1.18 Attacks per second

Crit chance for Trist: 0 + 30% = 30%
Attack Speed for Trist: [[0.625)/(1-0.04734)] x [100 + (4*9) + 50%]% = 1.22 Attacks per second, or 1.59/1.77/1.95/2.13/2.31 with Q activated

Phreak, I think Attack Speed might be slightly less intuitive than crit chance.

Yeah, but different champs have different base attack speeds, so while the crit chance on PD will be identical for every champ, a certain chance of dealing double damage, the attack speed can be different for each champ.

I'm highly against this as even the resulting value isn't useful by any means.

We shouldn't forget that Attack Speed modifies the **Attacks per Second** and not **Cooldown per Attack**. This is an important difference. (althought they are the same)
For example: 
{{item:1042}} on {{champion:119}} gives **0.10185** attacks per second. This is nowhere near useful for anything. 

It would look completely different if the result would result in this:
{{item:1042}} on {{champion:119}} reduces the cooldown of auto-attacks by **0.192 seconds per attack**

The player can grasp the *reduced cooldown per attack* much more easily than the *attacks per second*. But this is a problem which is fundamentally for League of Legends as everything is calculated and reduced to *attacks per second*.


######Note: The example is calculated with a level 0 Draven.
Actually, the first incantation is more useful to me, while the second one looks useless.

Quick Phreak!

Add up these percentages: 11 * 3.8% + 18% + 25%. then do the multiplication in your head to get total AS, and then figure out the AS increase with finishing a phantom dancer, or should you spend the gold on a BFS which will give you about 40% more AD at this point in the game.

Times up, if you didn't do the maths mentally by the time you finished reading it, you wouldn't have time to do it in game.

Now, imagine if the tooltip for PD in the store said "+50% base attack speed (+0.217 attacks per second)." Boom, you can use 0.217 and compare to your current as to get a rough percentage increase, *0.217 is about 20% of 1.127, I'd rather have the BFS.*

(Of course, I have a set build order and always finish items, but damn if it's hard to figure out which AS / crit items are better DPS increases without resorting to a spreadsheet).

I don't think you should be surprised. It is true (obviously) that Attack Speed and Crit Chance are both presented as percentages. But that doesn't mean they're exactly the same sort of entity. The difference is that Crit *Chance* is just that--a *probability* to deal extra damage--whereas Attack Speed is a *multiplier* that applies to a property of every autoattack. They're two different types of statistic that just happen to be both expressed as percentages.

Since you like looking at things mathematically, I'll try to describe what I think you see. Both stats appear in a formula for *time-averaged* damage as multipliers of the form (1 + TotalStatMod), ignoring crit damage modifiers for simplicity. But they only look similar mathematically when you do the time-average (uh, I guess we call that DPS :P). Otherwise, they are intuitively slightly different (which I've tried to explain in English in the first paragraph). In other words, when you say "I'm actually surprised" and explain why, I think you've missed something that's part of others' intuition.

All that said, I personally think the way Attack Speed boosts are presented is fine as it is, especially since you can mouse over your Attack Speed at any time to see the base you're working from, if you want to compare it to other characters'. Maybe in tutorials or something you could make it clear that different champions have different base Attack Speed?

Attack Speed isn't confusing.

It never has been confusing.  People are just trying to find more stuff to be confused about for no reason.

Agreed... It took me forever before I realized exactly how AS stacks...
Also, I find it odd how Wooglet's Witchcap says how much AP you gain from its passive, but Rabadon's Deathcap doesn't...

> Agreed... It took me forever before I realized exactly how AS stacks...
> Also, I find it odd how Wooglet's Witchcap says how much AP you gain from its passive, but Rabadon's Deathcap doesn't...

Very good point, even the new Spirit of the Ancient Golem lists it's bonus health... I don't understand why Rabadon's still doesnt
Actually, if you hover over it in your items, I am 99% sure it shows you how much AP it gives. Seen it multiple times before.

Why not have the actual amount of attack speed show up in parentheses after the percent?
Ex: Dagger +15% (0.094) Attack Speed
It would be like how percent health scaling things are portrayed.

I think this might be the best choice, since you get a more whole number to latch on to in terms of what gives a lot or a little attack speed, rather than just a string of a seemingly tiny decibel number.
I agree. I find AS rather confusing in this way. I understand that it's important for Champions to have different scaling for AS, but there must be a better way to represent it to the players.
